channel.title: Comments on: Calculating Week-To-Date values using DAX
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Ben Lezin
item.dc:creator: Ben Lezin
item.description: The code above and all time intelligence functions in tabular projects don't work in spite of referenced date dimension that appears to be correct. Can anyone help?
item.content:encoded:
The code above and all time intelligence functions in tabular projects don’t work in spite of referenced date dimension that appears to be correct.
Can anyone help?

item.title: By: Ben Lezin
item.dc:creator: Ben Lezin
item.description: Does anyone know if there is a bug with SSDT for SQL Server 2012 SP1 that precludes time intelligence functions in tabular projects? For example, when I implement the code above for week to date, it only returns the core measure value. This is true for any time intelligence function I use, even though the fact table is correctly referenced by the date dimension and the date dimension doesn't have any gaps. Thanks!
item.content:encoded:
Does anyone know if there is a bug with SSDT for SQL Server 2012 SP1 that precludes time intelligence functions in tabular projects?
For example, when I implement the code above for week to date, it only returns the core measure value. This is true for any time intelligence function I use, even though the fact table is correctly referenced by the date dimension and the date dimension doesn’t have any gaps.
Thanks!

item.title: By: Louis
item.dc:creator: Louis
item.description: David H. Thanks for sharing. I've been scratching heads trying to implement the WTD function and your dax query helped.
item.content:encoded: David H. Thanks for sharing. I’ve been scratching heads trying to implement the WTD function and your dax query helped.

item.title: By: David Hager
item.dc:creator: David Hager
item.description:
Just wanted to let you know that I found a modified way to calculate week-to-date that requires no calculated column.
=CALCULATE(SUM('Internet Sales'[SalesAmount]), DATESBETWEEN(Dates[ActualDate], LASTDATE(Dates[ActualDate])-WEEKDAY(LASTDATE(Dates[ActualDate]),2)+1, LASTDATE(Dates[ActualDate])))
item.content:encoded:
Just wanted to let you know that I found a modified way to calculate week-to-date that requires no calculated column.

=CALCULATE(SUM(‘Internet Sales'[SalesAmount]), DATESBETWEEN(Dates[ActualDate], LASTDATE(Dates[ActualDate])-WEEKDAY(LASTDATE(Dates[ActualDate]),2)+1, LASTDATE(Dates[ActualDate])))
